reviewText:
Yes, Deadwood may have extensive profanity, and some graphic sex, but guess what, that's how the real Deadwood was! Deadwood was an illegal settlement in the Black Hills territory made up of mostly gruff miners, and people who wanted to profit from them. These men weren't polite, friendly, or even hospitable. They DID curse ever other word, because that was the vernacular of the uneducated pioneer. As far as graphic sex, women in deadwood at that time were mostly prostitutes or dancing girls. it was not a place for polite young society women.

There have been a lot of western TV series, but this is by far the best, and probably the most accurate.

The acting is superb, especially from Ian Mcshane, Timothy Olyphant, and Powers Boothe. They really bring life into their characters. The shows blends the real-life people and fictional characters well. It's a believable hybrid. The sets are superb, and they really give the feel of a true pioneer town.

So, if you're looking for one of the best shows on TV, and you love westerns(especially historically acurate ones), you'll love Deadwood.

The overuse of profanity and sexual scenes really detracts from what Deadwood could really be.  It's too bad that it has to sell itself to sex and profanity starved people in order to survive.

For Example, "High Noon" starring Gary Cooper is the best western ever made and it has not sex or profanity, just great acting, a great story and great music.  I would recommend that people avoid this series like the plague until the writers and produces stop relying on the aformention central theme of how cool non-stop profanity sound in someone's living room.

JM

St Paul

As with my review of the first season (which can be seen by clicking "See all my reviews" directly above this) I'm not going to comment on the acting, the story or anything of that sort.  Again, I gave it a five star rating, and that should imply my opinion well enough.

This time around I want to comment on the delay of the DVD release and the price of the set.

The delay, while unfortunate, is actually a good thing.  The third season of Deadwood was originally set to air concurrently with the sixth season of The Sopranos.  However, after HBO executives saw the first half of the third season, they felt the show had sufficient strength to not need to piggyback on the ratings of The Sopranos.  So Deadwood and Big Love switched time slots, with Deadwood moving to this summer.  So Deadwood is no longer The Sopranos' little brother.  This shows the confidence that HBO has in the show, and that means the show isn't going away any time soon.

As for the price of the set, keep in mind that HBO is a subscription based network -- meaning they don't make any money from advertising or product placement, which is what pays for most programming on network television (thus the need to charge more than other networks for the DVD releases of their shows).

HBO has something like 25-50 million subscribers, I believe, so most of the country hasn't seen a single episode of the season when it comes out on DVD.  Compare that to shows like Law & Order, 24, and Desperate Housewives which are free to anyone with a TV, so anyone interested in those shows has probably already seen at least half of the season by the time the DVD comes out.

I don't know specific numbers for Deadwood, or any of the other shows that I mentioned, but I do know that HBO spent approximately $4 million per episode of Carnivale, which, while a great show, never had anywhere near the popularity that Deadwood has.

So, yes, the set costs a bit of money.  And, yes, we did have to wait a little longer for the set than most of us would have liked.  But any comments about greed are unfounded.

Unparalleled writing, set design, costume and acting make Deadwood the greatest show on television currently and one of the best in history. Well fleshed out characters and multiple intertwining plot lines leave you on the edge of your seat wanting to see what happens next. Deadwood as a series is nothing less than genius and I can not wait until season three starts in June. Highly recommended.

Deadwood is one of my favorite shows to watch because it has the most interesting characters. Ian McShane is great as Al Swearengen, the owner of the Gem Saloon. Deadwood is a great show because the whole idea of seeing what one of the towns on the Sioux territories would behave with very little law enforcement. It is one of the most accurate historical shows I have ever watched and even though there is a lot of profanity, it is still great. What I love about Deadwood is that you can really see how much the characters have changed from episode one to episode twelve of this season. It stinks that there are only twelve episodes but they are better than most twenty-two episode shows.

If you are familiar with the way HBO makes their series, then Deadwood may be the right show for you. It may be the best HBO drama ever and it has one of the best casts of any show on TV now. I highly recommend this season of Deadwood it is even better than the first.

BUT!!!!!!!!There is NO reason that Season 1 or 2 wasn't out on DVD in time for Christmas. Now, moving it from March to June really makes me mad. Ive waited long enough for Season 3. To issue Season 2 a week before Season 3 starts is also nonsense. Get with the Program, HBO. WE WANT DEADWOOD ON DVD WITHIN 2 MONTHS of the Seasons ending!!!!!!!! I'll buy the Chinese Bootlegs off ebay, before I wait another year for the previous seasons release next time.

Despite a barrage of profanity in every episode, the script of Deadwood represents the best writing in television bar-none.  The characters are brilliantly developed by the show's writer, David Milch (of Hill Street Blues fame).  I eagerly await the third season's debut in June, but will also add the 2nd season DVD to my collection (which already includes Season 1) as soon as it is released in May.  This show is a masterful combination of fact-based drama(ableit not a "true story"), and brilliant acting from the cast including Ian McShane, Powers Boothe, William Sanderson, W. Earl Brown, and others.  As you watch this show for the first time, be reminded the profanity is there to add authenticity from the period.  In my opinion, Deadwood is one of the best series ever created for television.  Enjoy!

Were probley the two best episodes of the season but still everyone is great. The Show is HBO's lifeline now considering in 2007 The Sopranos will be gone and By then HBO will have lost their last highest rated series (Losing Sex and The City & then in 2005 losing Six Feet Under)They are supporting Deadwood so much that they already started a 4th Season to air on HBO in 2007or2008. Deadwood is perhaps the best show HBO has made, and that's saying something. There is no other TV show, barring perhaps 'The Wire', which is written with such a keen ear for dialogue and with such fleshed out characters. Season 2 is just as good, if not better, than the first series. It moves with slightly more pace and some of the more interesting characters, such as Cy Tolliver and Alma Garrett, are explored in greater depth. Tolliver - played by the incredible Powers Boothe - truly becomes a force to be reckoned with in this second series. The powerplays between him and Al Swearengen make for some of the most interesting television one could hope to see.

Among other things, we see in season two the return of Bullock's wife and son; the softer side of Al Swearengen; a sadistic geologist with a keen eye for gold; and blood-letting between Mr. Wu and a chinese rival from San Francisco. Throughout, we are treated to a healthy dose of Deadwood's trademark violence and profanity, the latter of which rolls of the tongue with surprising eloquence. Swearengen makes certain curse words sound as if they are as natural as 'if', 'and' or 'but'.

Ultimately, the most outstanding features of this series are the following:

1) Al Swearengen - again, as in the first series, Ian McShane is amazing.

2) Cy Tolliver - Powers Boothe devours every scene he's in.

3) Seth Bullock - Timothy Olyphant's sheriff walks the streets of Deadwood like a cauldron about to teem with furious anger. The addition of his wife and son, and his illicit affair with Alma Garrett, add further tension.

Pick up series two when it comes out. Strangely, it's already out here in Australia!

There was a time many years ago when westerns were a prime time staple on television. Now finding any at all, let alone a really good one, is almost impossible. Deadwood was one  of the best cable westerns ever made. Great characters, interesting storylines and a real authenticity (except for the dialog which takes getting used to) to what life must have been like back in those days. Ian McShane steals the show as the villain you love to hate (but never completely)  and who yet in his own gruff manner sometimes displays uncharacteristic kindness. It's a shame it only lasted three seasons. If your a western buff like me than don't miss this series.

My husband and I recently finished a cross country driving trip and one of our stops was Deadwood, SD. After learning from other travelers that the HBO series was based on this historic city, I knew I had to watch the series. Needless to say, I was thrilled that the entire 3 seasons were available on Amazon Prime and free! I have finished all of seasons 1 and 2 and I'm starting 3. I am truly enjoying binge watching episodes. According to our guides in Deadwood, several of the characters and some of the locations that have survived the fires are actual historic figures and places. They have taken some artistic license with the story lines, but I can see where they might have needed to do that to move the story forward and not have to introduce new characters to incorporate some of the history. It is by no means historically accurate. It does show the viewer how challenging life was then--virtually no laws, and you would have been at the mercy of whomever had the money and power. The language is raw for anyone who does not like that sort of thing, and I have wondered if they really used the f-bomb back then as much as they do in the series. Take the time to look up the major figures. Deadwood has a web page which will nicely round our your viewing. Worth your time to watch this series.

We would have never settled the west as everyone would be dead), the story is typical HBO production quality great.  Just watch the first 3 seasons knowing you will be left forever hanging because HBO decided it was to expensive (PLEASE) to complete the series.

I finally gave a thought about the series "DEADWOOD" after watching Season 1, Season 2, and Season 3.  It was all about a collection of people back in the middle 1870s that owned business, as foul as they were, in Deadwood, South Dakota, I think.  When you say a program was lusty, with colorful language, that wouldn't exactly fit what I have been watching.  Nudity, including full frontal, cussin' like you haven't heard since the last time the ships were in, and the Sailors started drinkin'.  Having the "women of the night" in every episode, along with the killin, doesn't exactly make it an enjoyable series, but I must admit, even though I advised myself not to watch it, I watched each and every episode, from Season 1 through Season 3, and it did get better as the series continued.  I understand there are other Seasons available through Home Box Office, and maybe by the end, it would have some redeeming values to write about.  Probably not much worse than a real-life Cowboy picture in the 60s.
Great story, but only reason why only 4 stars is the over use of the "F" word. It's over kill and get's in the way of the story in my opinion.

This is my go to show when I exercise in the morning. It has a number of overlapping plot lines and transition points, so it's easy to find a stopping point mid-episode and then pick back up the next day.

One of my favorite things about this show is there are no pure "white hat" good guys, instead everyone has his or her flaws. There are, however, a couple of characters that are almost pure evil. Some of the more cutthroat characters turn out over time to have redeeming qualities after all.

My only criticism of the show is the overuse of profanity. I don't object to the use of expletives, but this show takes it to the extreme, to the point where it becomes almost comical, and definitely distracts from the story. There's a lot of gruesome violence too, but that seems to fit better with the overall story.

One of the best shows on television when it originally appeared, and it still fascinates today. I'm amazed at how much of the show I recall after not having seen these episodes since they aired from 2004-6.  I remain in the spell of the Shakespearean dialog, and the rotating Greek chorus of actors whose conversations, which can happen at any time, enlighten us on both past and current events. You have to listen to this show like no other in order to keep up. The acting and their intensity in every scene is hypnotic. If Deadwood was airing for the first time today, this uniquely-written program would be just as rave-worthy.

I'm a Deadwood fan at my core. There's a tinge of class when it comes to this show, you slowly love each of the characters and what they have developed into over the course of the shows short lived tenure. This is one of the few crime noire shows you tend to just love the protagonist (antagonistic by nature) crime Lord more as each season moves forward.

Where in shows like The Sopranos or boardwalk empire, you tend to dislike the main crime Lords more and more as you are exposed to the sub human parts of their psyche. In Deadwood I found myself loving Ian Mcshane's 'Al Swarangin' more and more as I watched.

Overall I'd issue the show as an excellent mix between The Sopranos and mad men, in that it created what I'd assume is a somewhat fair representation of the Deadwood camp in the early stages of the gold rush while mixing in some great elements of crime dramas of today.

The acting is top notch as are the production values, especially the costume designers and set designers, builders, and decorators. Due to the casting, almost every character, including the background extras, are 100% believably authentic. The only exception here is the character Jane who is neither believable, nor from my research and reading, accurate. The fault here lies not with the actress portraying Jane, though I think she was miscast, but with the writers who developed the character. All of the above attributes, notwithstanding the Jane character, combine to lead the viewer to believe they are peeking through a 60" HD time-window into an 1876 mining town in the Black Hills of the Dakota territory.

In my opinion, the biggest fault is the language (dialog) which is very stilted, archaic, and indirect. It may perhaps be accurate, but it does at times make the dialog difficult to follow and even to understand what the characters are talking about or referring to. And this doesn't even include the excessive vulgarity from everyone including the female characters. It seems as if every second or third word from every character is either the "F" word or a common vulgarity referring to a person performing fellatio. While I am quite sure that today's vulgarities were well known in 1876, I am also equally sure they weren't so liberally used as is depicted in this show. Because of the language, one sometimes might feel they are being verbally assaulted.

Also in my opinion, the sexual situations depicted should be a little less explicit and porn-like. The imagination is much more powerful than is the actual visual, which is why reading a book is always better than seeing the movie. If you are old enough to remember "Vargas Girls" and the "Playboy" mags of the 1950s and early 19660s, you understand the allure and seduction of almost, but not quite seeing, to the vulgarity of "Hustler". This is definitely not a show for those of tender age or of tender morals.

As a result of the unrealistic character, Jane, the excessive use of vulgarisms, and explicit sexual situations, I gave the show 4 stars. Nevertheless, it is worth the time to watch; if you can handle the language and the sex.

Maybe the best season of the best show in the last fifteen or twenty years; only House M.D. even came close, and that was network, with all the attendant limitations. For all you Amazon customers who are offended by "salty" language, stay away; for all of you who enjoy meticulous, exquisite television drama peppered with shocking, realistic scenes of spoken and physical violence, POUNCE! How HBO ever canceled this show for some of the things that eventually took its slot -- Lena Dunham? SERIOUSLY?! -- is a mystery they have never explained. It's not like Martin Scorcese: this is not just violence porn; this is writing so far over the heads of people like Scorcese that you end up looking at comic books like Boardwalk Empire (with all apologies to Jack Huston, who was great on that show) in total bewilderment.

This has got to be the best television series I have ever watched. The language used is not for the faint of heart but the reality of the show leaves nothing to the imagination.  I enjoyed the show so much that I finally visited the real town of Deadwood in South Dakota. Many of the characters in the series are taken from life and are still part of the deadwood history. The only disappointing aspect of this wonderful television drama is that it appears there was supposed to be a fourth season and it never came about.  This leaves a few unanswered questions making the last show of the third season very frustrating. Still I would recommend anybody who loves excellent acting, colorful characters and a true real-life reality in a series should begin as soon as possible to view this epic presentation before it is no longer available on Amazon.

After watching a full season and a third of Deadwood, I have decided to stop watching it.  The multiple overuse of three ways to describe characters, i.e., F'ers, MF'ers, and CS'ers, and the additional over use of the F word in all of its iterations to describe surprise, hatred, suspicion, joy, sorrow, love, and almost any other emotion, amounts to an overworked clich that leaves me cold instead of merely disgusted. Also, there is not a single character in the production who I would speak to on the street, much less invite into my home through the medium of television. I originally decided to put up with these turnoffs in order to watch and see any redeeming value in the episodes, but I found none.

I had never heard of the tv series, Deadwood.  A friend mentioned it in passing and said that the DVDs was available at the library.  She said that the series was highly praised for it's authenticity of the old west.  Well, I am a great fan of my prime membership so decided if it was there and it was.  It was free to watch because of my prime membership.  Before I started watching it I mentioned that I was going to start the series.  They told me how the had bought all three seasons at a big box store and the show was great.  I started to watch it and was hooked from the start.  The flavor of the time, the characters, the moral good and bad had me.  It was hard to get used to listening to the crude language and the violence but watching the good and evil play off of each other and seeing that the good could be bad and the bad could be good was fascinating.  I would highly recommend all three seasons and just wish that there were more seasons to watch.

This is my second Amazon review of Deadwood. The first was offered without the urging of Amazon back in the stone age when we put shiny plastic disks into black boxes which made pictures and sound appear on the glass screen of another big box we would all gather around.
This review OTOH is in reply to the gentle urging of Bezos et al who we assume are benignly monitoring our streaming habits and seeing an uptick in Deadwood streaming. You might think they are seeking a pulse in the era of 6" phone screens and ADHD as it relates to binge watching.
Let it go. Robot emails get sent to everybody that watches anything on Prime and we ain't special. That's about the size of it.... but...

Let's not forget that Deadwood remains the best example of how tele-dramas can be made that do not insult the viewers gray matter, how the overlay of contemporary mores and attitudes can be used to hook us in with familiarity and then keep us hooked because it uses that familiarity to immerse us in a world that is both as compelling a reproduction of a time and place as is likely possible, and at the same time so alien to everything we think we know that it's more times than not uncomfortable to digest.

Period series get saddled with employing current social dilemmas into their plots. That kind of proselytizing can be suffered in more mainstream fluff but it's a dealbreaker for me. Then there's the commensurate revisionism that moves to reshape the social structure of the period to reflect what we would prefer it had been or worse, what we want ours to be now. Drivel. Actors, writers and directors are under some obligation to play ball and the final product often reflects the creation by committee approach.
Deadwood not so much. Deadwood was in your face about a time and place and the people trying to survive in that world. Profane, illiterate, filthy and unstoppable. Not unstoppable like action heroes, unstoppable like small people eking out a survival strategy daily, sometimes by the minute. The unrepentant writing, remarkable performances and the most authentic sets I have ever seen, big screen or small... well sometimes, too often, somebody invokes the "magic " of motion pictures. Here's one show that fits the bill. Magic.

10 years have passed since the last season and the impact of Deadwood still resonates.

Watch Peaky Blinders and see a current example of how the Deadwood form has been applied to the period following the Great War in England. That show is not Deadwood, but it is very good. Good enough to be spoken of in the same breath as Deadwood.

I have a video collection of thousands of titles which we rarely take advantage of.  The endless selection that the net provides is more in sync with our mantra to not dwell on the past when so much is available. That's yet another rule that Deadwood is an exception to.

Maybe there is something to the complaint that there's nothing any good on tv anymore. Maybe on your tv. On our tv, we can just stream Deadwood.

Deadwood is a milestone in television history. Engaging storylines, well-developed characters, and intrigues aplenty make for exciting viewing. Actor Ian McShane, in the role of Al Swearengen, is a revelation. It is one of the finest performances committed to film, in movie or television. To watch what could have been a typical TV villain become a deeply complex and fascinating character in the hands of this master performer is an experience one must not neglect.

Has Really foul language, it's not just the words but the hoity toity use of the English language that really distorts true western life in the 1800's. The life may have been very hard, people rough, whores, gambling, tough times for people, but this series doesn't truly depict the struggles of the common folk, it tries to depict the seamy side of the card shark, gambling proprietor that also runs the town red light house, both Chinese and Caucasian. Plots are fun to figure out and follow, good acting by many of the characters. If it had a little more appropriate language and script, i would have given it 5 stars.

Cons:
Each season gets more violent, sexually explicit and vulgar. This is certainly not for an audience adverse to foul language, explicit sex and violence. The story line goes into very dark evil parts of people and society as the wild west begins to become exploited by the rich and corrupt.
Pros:
The story line is full of intrigue and completely unpredictable. Their is good in most people somewhere deep down no matter how evil they appear and their behaviors. Romantic relationships twist and turn while love continues in different forms. Sadness exists in most unexpected ways and the reactions of the community members is are touching and unexpected in some of the nastiness of all. If you follow the story line and ignore the vulgarity it is a story that likely portrays the real will west versus earlier story lines. It is an ugly journey from wild to governance.
Summary:
I enjoyed this season with some tears, laughter, shock and rejection of the vulgarity. Somewhat shocked that I was able to distance myself from the foul language, etc. Totally unexpected story line. I binge watched many nights.

I  have not yet finished the second season of Deadwood but always look forward to the next episode.  There are many surprising twists and turns to the plot which keep you involved in the characters' lives and the terrific hardships of the times in which they lived, many of which are shocking and vulgar, few of which are pleasant but there are those times also.  It is a time of rough and tumble existence.  The sets are amazing, such as the fist fight in the mud, the recovery from traumas with little or no anesthesias available, the lives of the "whores," the failed attempts at peacekeeping, the stagecoaches.  You are drawn into that world without realizing it.  The series is beautifully produced down to every detail.

I believe that this series is among the best pieces of work I have ever seen. The writing is deeply provocative, and the execution of its intricacies by the actors is riveting. Every conversation is, at the very least entertaining, but more often as revealing of the human condition as any in Shakespeare, in my opinion. I am currently watching the series from the beginning and I look forward t every minute that I can spend watching it. I revel in the language and the skillful delivery of it. I enthusiastically endorse this work with the highest rating.

Also, it seems the writers are in a competition to see how many times they can use the f word in a sentence.

Wonderful series...
  Shakespeare meets Greek tragedy, meets the past lifestyle where I live now.  I live in the central Colorado mountains where in the same time period the identical search for the color (more silver than gold) was going on.  I care take 4 old mining claims up at 10,000 ft. elevation and counting, with 2, old log cabins that are 100 plus years old, ruins of old small settlements and evidences of the mines. I find myself imagining what life must have been like there and down in the nearest towns.  This whole series paints a wonderful glimpse into what I know and have heard my area of the Rockies was like.
  I am a woodworker and have Friends in the movie industry.  It is all illusion created for entertainment but this series creates a great one an all ways from sets, writing , directing and of course acting.
  Watch and then watch again.  I watched for my second time with my room mate while working in Antarctica.  She had not seen it and quickly became addicted.

Tuning out the language, I absolutely love this series!  My son-in-law refers to it as "Cowboy Porn", but honestly, I was able to look beyond any of that & was just so into the time period, the surroundings, who the people were & how they lived.  I am so into this period of history with researching my ancestors...BOTH sides of the family on my mother's side initially settled in Dakota Territory.  My Great Grandfather, Fritz Giselman(Bavaria) was even the Butcher at Fort Buford right around the time Sitting Bull surrendered.  Fritz met my Great Grandmother, Elizabeth(Bessie) Gynther(Finland) as she was a cook for an Army Officer & his family at Ft. Buford.  They were married in 1895 in Williston, North Dakota, after Fort Buford closed.(I was thrilled to find a pic of their second born, my Great Uncle "Bill" Giselman, on ebay!!) They farmed & raised cattle for 6 years outside Minot, ND before homesteading in Alberta, Canada.  What they went through was just miraculous!  People who think they are struggling now, really need to get into the history of this country & see how & what people went through before us & the path carved for our freedom...intensely interesting!  I enjoyed all 3 season's & was extremely disappointed they stopped at season 3!!

Set in a gold mining camp in the Dakota territories. Ian McShane plays the town strongman as owner of the saloon, gambling and whore house. Timothy Olyphant comes to town to open a hardware store with his partner. There characters grow as the camp grows. Very good cast of characters. Very intriguing plot twists, some expected and some totally unexpected. There is a lot of nudity and fowl language, which is to be expected from a period piece such as this. Great for binge watching during period of cold or bad weather. Highly recommended!!

The entire Deadwood series is the best and most accurate portrayal of what a raw Western frontier town was actually like every made.  Outstanding acting, directing and production.  Vast majority of major figures are real and the telling of Deadwood does not violate the known facts from the dozen or so characters who's real name was used.  Writers used Territorial newspapers and personal letters as a guide to events accurately played out.

I lived in Rapid City many years ago and had been to Lead and Deadwood. After watching this, I want to make another visit. I have told several friends about this series. I love anything with Timothy Olyphant in it but honestly, I just love the whole Deadwood series.  The ONLY and single reason I didn't rate it a 5 is because of the overly gratuitous use of one particular cuss word, that being c@(k sucker, and you hear it at least, I'm estimating, 20 or 30 times per episode!  I am so far from being a prude but it's just makes me scratch my head as to what the logic was to include it in the script over and over and over and it's used by most of the entire cast and not by just one single character.  Obviously, I still love the show and can't wait to finish watching all of the other seasons because I'm totally into it and want to see what happens. The repetitive use of that word just starts to take away from the show to me.  It's actually annoying and my 27 year old daughter was in the house while I was watching an episode and she even commented on how often they say it.  Ha, who knows, maybe it was a very popular word in those days and its inclusion is historically accurate, LOL.
If this was the old west, I am glad I did not live in those times.

The story, the actors, the acting are truly excellently done. And, I suspect the scenery gives a reasonably accurate remembrance of what gold rush mining camps, the sawmill towns, land rush camps, and small, rapidly growing settler farming towns of America's Wild West years, the mid to late 1800's, looked like. However, every scene is running-over with unnecessary cursing, overwhelming, nauseating foul language, and an almost total emphasis on prostitutes and dishonest, murderous bar owners. Such heavy reliance on this kind of lead character once again comes across as an enormous failure of "secular" atheist Hollywood writers, directors, and producers to be able to fully comprehend normal people or to understand the true source, the faith, character, personal strength, and determination which built our great nation.

Deadwood is a must-watch. The show has everything. Outstanding performances, quality writing, impeccable production design...I could go on. Ian McShane's turn as Al Swearengen is awe-inspiring. At times brutal and ruthless, at others tragic and heart-wrenching, Deadwood manages to do what so few television programs can; it takes you to the place that you're watching. You'll feel like you've sat down at a Pharaoh Table in the Gem Saloon. You'll feel like you're in the queue in "Farnum's absurd little restaurant". You may even become so absorbed as to smell the muck of the thoroughfare, the exotic smells of the Chinese Immigrant quarter, and the scent of hope, folly, and violence wafting through the trees.

Season 2 in particular is a highlight of the (depressingly) short run of the series. Set some months after the finale of Season 1, we are introduced to the machinations of George Hearst via his scheming and monstrous representative Francis Wolcott. Sheriff Bullock (Timothy Olyphant)'s family joins him in the camp early on and he struggles to integrate him into his life. Sol Star and Trixie continue their dalliances. The crew of the Gem Saloon are as entertaining and hopelessly dim-witted as ever. Please...stop reading and watch this show. You'll thank me for it.

Very enjoyable historically based drama.  Some of the characters are based upon real people - Al Swearangen, Bullock & Star, Calamity Jane, etc, while others are created based upon a combination of people.  There is a lot of profanity in this series, which gives the impression of Deadwood being a place that's operating outside the confines of normal civilization.  The story lines this season are based on Bullock's wife arriving in Deadwood, ending his relationship with Alma Garrett, power struggles between Swearangen and Cy Tolliver, and impending annexation to the state - South Dakota, or maybe Montana or Wyoming.  Well written and well acted, and very much in keeping with the way things occurred around 1890 at that place (although I've read that the writers replaced the 4-letter words of the day with current "cuss words", because the cusses from 125 years ago sound funny, not profane).
Fast moving and gripping. Continues the tale from season 1, as profane and violent as before.

Season 2 is even better than 1 which I wouldn't have thought possible. Mitch's ability to weave so many characters' stories into one unified narrative is unsurpassed. There's everything you need for a rollicking rough ride: suspense, tragedy, comedy, love, violence (his fight scenes are the best I've ever seen - but warning: realistic & hard to watch), irony, greed. He seems to always be saying: nothing human is alien to me. And "there but for the grace of God go I."

Deadwood was without a doubt some of the finest TV I've ever sampled. You've got your Western, you've got your prurient interest quotient, you've got your "slightly soiled hero" in Sheriff Seth Bullock, played by a much younger (than current character Raylen Givens on "Justified) Timothy Olyphant, and you've got Ian McShane as Swearengen, a character about as hard to pigeon-hole as he would be to sneak up on. All in all, about as good as TV gets.
Excellent
The characters are building up some very interesting scenarios and repercussions are gonna fall...

Yes, the language is tough in Deadwood, as are the images...but we got through THE SOPRANOS, didn't we, and those scripts cannot compare with the Shakespeare-like dialogue, monologues, soliloquies, banter, puns, etc. that are the backbone of conversation in this (dare I say it) God-forsaken place in the Wilds of The Dakotas.  It's ALL about the characters who totally drive these stories through the muddy, messy, mayhem that is the Main Street of this 'Camp'.  The feel of authenticity, the range of characters AND the range within each character is a thing of beauty in a setting that is completely desolate.  Do not dare miss a line of dialogue, or you will be instantly lost in the 'dust' of this twisting tale of passion, compassion, greed, and generosity of spirit.  Would rank DEADWOOD one of THE best series ever!

I've watched this 3 year series twice, and I can honestly say that this was one of the all time greats. I can't understand why HBO dropped it after the 3rd year. The writing of the  script is witty and exceptionally well done in the verbiage of the period. Second to that, the acting of said script. After that, I'd have to tip my hat to the authenticity of historical facts. They featured many historical people that were, in fact, in Deadwood at that time. Now, HBO did make some changes for dramatic license. Like making the Swerengen character from England instead of Oklahoma which was where he was  actually from. Other than that, everything else is true. Spend some time and enjoy this program. You won't regret it.

A great series that ended too soon, but you have to block out the overuse of shock language.

I absolutely loved the entire Deadwood production and, even though a friend had warned me it ends abrubtly, I was very disappointed when it just, boom, stopped. I thought it had at least a 4th season to go yet, should have looked ahead I guess.  The only thing I did not like about the show was the language as the big F, and the one word women really hate, was used every other word at times.  I can't believe people actually talked like that, even in the gold rush setting.  I am no prude by any means but the use of foul language went way overboard.  Other than that...it was one of the best shows I have ever watched.  Ian McShane was amazing as "Swearengen", what an actor that man is.  Hats off also to Robin Weigert (Calamity Jane) and Paula Malcomson (Trixie) for their superb acting.  I loved all the characters in the show but they really stood out. The opening scenes with the running horse and the music, never got tired of it.  The music is not at all anything I would normally listen to but I thoroughly enjoyed all the music/songs thoughout the entire show.

We're watching this for the second time, some ten years after its debut. This time we have the benefit of English subtitles, which adds to the pleasure because it is easy to not catch some of the brilliant dialog when relying by ear alone. It reminds me of Shakespeare with its grit, humor and understanding of human nature. There's really nothing else like it.

A TV series which is flawed in every possible dimension. The violence and crudeness is appalling. Yet I am drawn into caring about even the most despicable characters - not caring for them necessarily, but tremendously absorbed by  what happens to them. There is a balance between the clichd/iconic and the idiosyncratic and human aspects of the characters and the drama itself that reminds me of Shakespeare. It deepens and seems to become more free and more itself with every episode (I am still in the second season).

Having read some books written by people who faught in the Civil War, I have a familiarity with the way people talked back in that era.  So I find I hard to believe that the "F" word would be used at all and certainly not as excessively often as they do in this series.  People talk that way now but I doubt that they did back then.  It just doesn't seem authentic.  I'm not sure I will finish watching this series.  I really like historically correct and well made westerns, but this one is hard to watch.

This is one of those rare TV series that is so well-written and acted, directed and edited, that you cry when it ends.  And you really do in the case of DEADWOOD because they just cut it off way before it should have ended.  My understanding is that it wasn't because the ratings weren't good--people loved it--but the creator and the cable network had problems.  Really too bad.  But that doesn't make it any less of a must-see.  Ian McShane is hilarious and fabulous; Timothy Oliphant breaks out and the woman, whose name I am ashamed I cannot remember is a terrific foil for them all, as well as making the screen sizzle with Oliphant.

Once you get beyond the epic profanity and pigs eating one murder victim after the next, this is a sweeping Shakespearean-style tragedy with astonishingly complex characters, superb scenery, and unpredictable plotting. No, this isn't the real Deadwood, and not even Shakespeare talked like these guys. And I understand why many viewers were simply repulsed by the unceasing swearing and sexism, racism, bigotry and graphic sex and violence that, if you watch long enough, simply becomes embedded in the narrative. I do believe that movie violence can encourage violence in real life, but this series is different. In a classic sense, this descent into hell has a purging emotional effect because, deep inside, all of the characters are struggling against their own inner demons in an effort to be good, or to do good, or just to cope with their darker side. It is this soap opera, played out against a more mannered era than today, combined with the lawlessness of Deadwood and its foul-mouthed population that creates an unforgettable alternative universe from which we cannot look away. And it's hilarious at times.

Why 4 stars?  Well, Amazon has taken to pulling final seasons from Prime.  I have started watching several series where the final season was pulled off Amazon Prime!  WHAT!  This was very upsetting, and if I had to rate Amazon Prime, it would have gone from an EASY 5 stars, down to 1 or 2 for this move, which I have seen repeated on several series.  This is just lame.

So the highest I will rate an Amazon Prime series is 4 stars if it is awesome, and 2-3 stars if merely good.  The fact that I give Deadwood 4 stars is indicative of how great this show is.  It is only one of a few I would rate this highly, another being Band of Brothers, since it is great and luckily only one season, so Amazon cannot truncate the end on me.

My season one review:
"This show is not what I thought it would be. I was expecting a foul mouthed western (which it is) but it is also the story of a town coming together much like a family.
Also unexpected was the dark humor which mostly comes from the excellent Ian McShane playing the surprisingly sensitive Al Swearengen.
Often, with high quality television, it takes a few episodes for the characters to really gel and Deadwood is no exception.
This show really finds it's groove about halfway through the first season.
Highly recommended."

This series is absolutely one of the most quintessential American west series ever produced. The acting is incredible. Every plays an integral role in the series, and each character leaves you spellbound in their role. Ian McShane and Timothy Olyphant are seriously underrated Actors. Both make this series a must watch with their riveting acting. Also, what makes this series fascinating is the introduction of factual figures from the American West, such as Wild Bill Hickok, Wyatt Earp, Calamity Jane, etc. I don't know how accurate some of the storyline regarding these figures are, but nonetheless quite interesting.  I would rate Deadwood up there with The Soprano's, Orange is the New Black, and Breaking Bad. Anyone who has an interest in the raw and rugged life that must have been the wild west, I feel, would surely find this series to have great entertainment value. Unlike many series where you can see the writers creative waning as the season progress, Deadwood is as riveting the last few episodes as it was the very first. Why it ended so prematurely is beyond me. I suppose Ian McShane and Timothy Olyphant (Justified) decided to go on to do other things. I can earnestly say that after watching Deadwood S1-3, that both McShane and Olyphant are two of my favorite Actors. A must watch!
Love this serious! Can't for the life of me understand why they cancelled it :/

First, Tim Oliphant had a minor role in this series, do if you're a fan don't watch to see him in a star performance. The acting is good by all the cast, but the script and the dialogue are so offensive that I have decided I cannot finish the series. It's the most vulgar piece of writing that I have ever come across.  I am sure that Deadwood in 1873 was a wild raucus place, but the 21st century foul-mouth words did not exist back then. The language is so bad and so nonstop that it distracts you from any good points that the series might have. It makes you feel like you need a bath afterward to wash away some of the dung. What a waste of talent.

I am becoming more disappointed by the episode.  It seems that the writers are in a contest to see who can use the words f#*k and  c##*K S@#$Ker more in a scene.  I find it hard to believe that in the Victorian era, even in the back woods of the Dakotas,  this level of vulgarity would have been that common.  I have about given up on any semblance of historical accuracy or real entertainment value in this production.

I'll say it again, great story line but the use of the f-word is unintelligent and unnecessary.  I'm not all together opposed to using swear words when the story calls for it but these are ill placed and unnecessary.

Love this series.  Watching it for a second time and like it just as good as the first.

1876 Black Hills of the Dakota territory gold rush where anything goes in a settlement with no laws.  Murder, prostitution, alcohol and drug abuse are the norm.  It not only happens daily, it happens around the clock.  It's a story of dominance by a hand full of people, characters nearly larger then life itself, in a free for all capitalist dog eat dog environment - totally Darwinian.  As the story moves towards the thrid season, it's also a story of how raw power, already establish power can bribe and murder its way towards more established power as the settlement begins to vote for law and move away from frontierism. The drive to get the gold out of the ground is the engine that drives the settlement.  There does not seem anything like this series of which I am aware.  The characters are fully developed so much so that they jump out of the screen.  Warning:  if profanity, copulation, or murder - slicing throats bother you, you had better stay clear of this series because it happens continuously throughout.

Season 2 finds me completely hooked. Corruption abounds. Killing and bribery abound.  Everyone is scheming is they way of life for everyone.  I have enjoyed every episode.  I am amused by the contrast between the genteel language the characters affect, followed by/sprinkled with liberal use of profanity.  It is interesting how all of the so called "leading citizens" are only "leading citizens" because they are part of or associated with Swearengen's gang.

The foul language is excessive, not because it's foul, but because sometimes it is every other word. That is fine when someone is upset or in another context, but otherwise, at least in the first 5 episodes, it detracted from the story line because it's like hitting a cringe worthy verbal speed bump. I am sure that people in a mining town used profane, foul, 'bad' words as regular parts of their speech, but it's like the writers were 5 year olds learning a new word. There seems as if there should be some sort of non modern foul expletive/descriptive they could have thrown in there every few verbal eructions...
Having started with that caveat, I will say the rest of the dialog, and the sets, storyline and acting is excellent. Things are dirty, look like they smell bad, life is hard and unfair, people are fallible, greedy, murderous, and yet even the bad guys have a shining moment sometimes.
I enjoyed it very much.

I am in the third and last season and I don't want it to end. This has been the best western miniseries I've ever seen.  Even though the language is bad at times, I could over look it with the thought that it was probably the way they really expressed themselves back then. Actors were superb!

This review is after viewing all 3 seasons:  Wasn't nearly as good as I expected.  HBO missed a lot of opportunities on this one,  it really could have been something. One strange thing is the extreme overuse of the term "coc-sucker" which I truly don't mind in and of itself but in this show it is literally used in every sentence nearly every other word! Absolutely LOVE the series Deadwood.  It's one of the few series that I've gone back to watch over and over and over again.

It appears to be very accurate in its details and portrayal of characters that were 'real' people of the time period. It just sits them down into a life likely situations.  Again, all this attention to the details is what has made me and a lot of others watch it repeatedly.

My only criticism of the program is for the last season.  You can feel it in the last few episodes.  It feels like the Executive Producers and et al heard from HBO that it was to be the last season and told the writers to wrap-it-up.  And they did.  Kinda just changed purpose of the seasons basic storyline and just wrapped-it-up.  To me it feels incomplete.  I mean it's all still 4 stars good and if you weren't looking to closely you probably wouldn't mind or even notice.  It's good but the end of the story feels unfinished to me and not quite up to the same standards as the rest of the story, GREAT.

Ah yes, another downside is the profanity.  Lots of it.  Crudity, too.  But, again, that is probably the way it was for a bunch of men living together the way they were in those little gold mining towns.  No ladies around to civilize them.  Attention to the details in every way.

All that said I still give it a great 5 Big stars.

As in season 1, evolving multiple story lines are the rule of thumb in season 2.  Also like season 1, each episode of season 2 tends to include 1 or more soliloquys, often spoken by either Farnum and/or Swearengen.  This technique adds an interesting Shakespearean touch to the show - something rarely seen in 'westerns'.  The addition of a couple of new characters/sub-plots to the dynamic season 1 yields a season 2 that has you on the edge of your chair wondering what season 3 will bring!

I really enjoy this series, I love the conflict that is brewing between those of the "Camp" and George Hearst the greedy mining baron who has raped the Comstock and who has now set his sights on Deadwood, in the Black Hills of Dakota. Hearst has enlisted the aid  of the character, Si Torrington, played by Powers Booth, a nasty pimp and saloon owner, while the people in the camp are lined up behind Al Swearengen who owns a rival saloon with whores too, but Al is now friends with Seth Bullock , the Sheriff and Hardware store partner, and together they provide cover to those inhabitants who are afraid to stand up to Hearst and his minions. The photography is great as is the dialogue, and there is no lack of blood and gore!

I watched all three seasons in two weeks.  A soap opera for guys with violence and tough character development.

Second season, even more than the first, shows the talents of the writing and production group plus the fine acting of McShane, Oliphant and an ensemble of talented people (some of whom you will recognize from Justified!) who bring realism and depth to the period piece about the post war (Civil War) expansion of the west and the culture and characters who made it what it was.  Deadwood is a great model for human development and expansion with all of its pros and cons.  Well thought out scripts loosely parallel real events and people blurring the historical accuracy in the spirit of better story telling.  Who knows if history is accurate or just the first attempt.  Deadwood is a great chronicle of the west, probably more so than "Lonesome Dove' or other squeeky clean docu drama dusters.

An entire episode focused on a character ( who had, mysteriously, lost his English accent since the last season ) trying to pass a stone that was lodged in his bladder. A very bizarre and overly graphic series of scenes.

To be fair, I did not, and will not see the entire second season.  I only made it to the backed up bladder episode.  It is sad to see that this passes for a western.

Firstly, let me say that I DO NOT WATCH TELEVISION!  the last time I owned a tv myself was about1990.  I just wasn't willing to give up READING time to watch poorly produced, badly acted, atrociously written material I had already seen when I was 12 years old (a long time ago) rehashed and regurgitated.  While I have total respect for performance art, not much of that carried over to production broadcast tv.  A few exceptions existed of course, as talent will almost always exert itself given opportunity.  Notably in my opinion were "Soap" and "Night Court" which I saw a few episodes of (no disclosure of tv owner or positions during viewing available) and occasionally some other one (the "Designing Women"  guest starring Gerald McRaney).  I was delighted to see him again in "Deadwood" as the totally despicable George Hurst.

Recently, I was given a 30 day free trial of Amazon Prime, and since I had only ever heard a couple of references to "Deadwood" as "revisionist western" I plopped my self down for "a few minutes" because Timothy Olliphant was brilliant in the two episodes of "Justified" I was exposed to (details deleted) based on work by one of my favorite authors, the absolute master, Elmore Leonard.

The few turned into a virtual marathon as this was much more the "West" I imagined than "Big Valley" or "Petticoat Junction".  I was enthralled!  Every member of the cast was at the top of the curve in every respect, the set and action superb and I met one of the all time best "bad guys" in the persona of Al Swearingin.

For absolutely top notch entertainment, chance to observe performance detail and production value way beyond the usual. and the resulting smile at the end of each episode, I have never seen anything close enough to be called competition to this series.

The second season was rich with detailed character expansion on the development from the first season.  There are simply too many examples to start singling out  rants and interactions, but the dialog and soliloquies will go down in my personal history of visual drama as one of the top three all time best productions of the fantasy labeled "Wild West".

I submit that cable development during my hiatus away from the "small screen" has introduced many needed changes in our perception of drama (and comedy) in motion, and provided opportunity for many excellent actors to expand themselves beyond what formerly passed as "good tv", but it has also presented that opportunity to writers, directors and all the myriad staff required to  complete such demanding and detailed work.

My hat is off to everyone involved in this particular exposition, and if they had more stars than five, I would grant all of them.  While I am sure my kudos won't make much difference to the participants in this effort which is now in the "past"  I hope it will serve to induce others to watch and appreciate this magnificent effort.  You WILL NOT BE SORRY!
This is one of my all time favorite series. The acting, the writing, the visuals, everything about it is just so damn good. This show is a must see!

The acting and writing are so powerful in this sadly cancelled HBO gem that you get caught up in the ride and lose track of time.  The language may be salty, but the structure is so Shakespearean and the themes so relevant that the f bombs cease to matter to intelligent viewers. Outstanding sophomore season. Classic.

In my review of Deadwood's first season, I whined about Tim Olyphant's near-constant facial expressions of emotional constipation and apparent disgust. I am happy to say that in Season Two, his attentions have shifted to more familial concerns, with only the occasional pistol-whipping and painful grimace suggesting imminent outrage. Ian MacShane continues to shine as the center of power in Deadwood. The introduction of Garrett Dillahunt's new character, a quiet but homicidal emissary of an as yet unseen force  with whom Swearingin and Deadwood will have to contend, brings new intrigue. The issue of annexation becomes a central focus for Swearingin and the others, with Powers Boothe's Cy Tolliver pulling strings on the side and generally leaving the viewer to wonder just how much power and influence he'll manage to gather for himself if his association with Dillahunt's Wolcott character doesn't first blow up in his face.
Tragedy looms as the season comes to a close, but no spoilers here, my friend. As always, this motley bunch of miners and misfits curses up a storm and leaves you wanting more!
Excellent. Every actor lived their part to make Deadwood a highly entertaining work of art. Thank you for your hard work.
I started watching this series over again when Season 3 came out and it was just as good as when I watched it the first time.
Great acting and writing. Ian McShane is brilliant as is the rest of the cast! A real sense of what the old west was like.

Ian McShane is an awesome and dynamic leading character!  In fact, I believe his character is THE singlely most effective energy in this very successful series. Timothy Olyphant is excellent as well, but lacks the full dynamics of his character - like in the series, "Justified".  The scenery is probably authentic for the time and location, but visually unattractive.  Narrow streets, unshaven and cantankerously drunken townspeople, and the township roads - always narrow and wet - one wonders why folks would choose to live in an environment like this (other than the obvious gold prospect, of course).  With all that aside, this series is compelling, energic, and wonderfully addictive.  I'm so looking forward to the next season.  Doug

The comic Bard, if alive today, could have written this. Notwithstanding the constant, and I mean every 30 seconds or more, use of the F-bomb and/or C***Sucker, the dialogue is what makes this show so much fun! Especially in the hands of Ian McShane, who grabs the stage as his own every time he has the camera, and says these wonderful concoctions of language and thought that seem so out of place in a time like Deadwood, yet become as real a possibility as the horses in the street.

William Earl Brown is often the perfect foil, who hears his boss, struggles with us sometimes to make sense of it, eventually gets the gist, shrugs and moves on. Hard to imagine in print like this, but what fun!

And many others in this rich cast have their moments of literary flight. For a bunch of hardy self-preserving pioneers, for the most part without much of the education we would assume available at the time, they construct sentences that  sometimes baffle themselves, as well as many of our near illiterate college grads. Not everybody's cup of tea, especially in a western, but a total joy for oddballs like me.

The outstanding ensemble of characters also makes for a rich and rewarding viewing experience. Brad Dourif, Dayton Callie, William Sanderson, Jeffery Jones, Molly Parker, Keone Young, and especially Robin Weigert, as Calamity Jane, all make this show an actor's romp. They fill the screen each time they appear, and make it so much fun to watch and listen to them.

Timothy Oliphant may top the billing, but in season 2, at least, his Bullock often looks like a deer caught in headlights. I hate to say that, but he just seems as bewildered by it all as I suspect too many potential viewers were. While Bullock seems a worthy grandfather to Marshall Givens, Bullock just can't seem to find his place in this town. He seems much too reactive, without his own center. Perhaps season 3 will change that.

It is Ian McShane's season, if not show. Swearengen provides most of the subtle storyline, on which most of the rest of the cast operate, directly or indirectly. A band of independent pioneers just wanting to make a living in the "uncivilized" wilderness, but realizing they need to come together to form a working society that eventually will not only embrace them, but protect them as well. A slow process, both on screen and for the viewer, and certainly not the expected storyline for a western. Swearengen's foresight and understanding are unexpected, as he tries to manipulate this bunch of rowdies into place. Herding cats, not cattle, comes to mind.

So, if you don't care for Shakespearian dialog with the F-bomb more than replacing "hath", and if you don't enjoy in your face acting, this is probably not the show for you.

But if you are delighted by language, come from Brooklyn like I do and therefore not notice the F-bomb as anything unusual, and if you love to see actors having lots of fun doing what they love, you'll enjoy almost every minute of this delightful comic series.

The only shame is that there is only 3 seasons!
One of the most beautiful shows to ever grace the television - And an important piece of poetic American history.

The success of a show is often measured in it's longevity. Law and Order ran for 20 years, ER ran form15, etc. But what makes good shows, especially dramas are whether or not they stay relevant while they endure. Mindless shows that follow a formula are great for the actors. They stay employed, but for the viewer, they become boring fast. There is a real growth to this show, not just in the characters, but in the events of the time as well. You can be the humanity creep out of each one of the while they fight their personal demons and grow as individuals they also fight to advance as a society. Impressive and well done.
I can't begin to express my height of interest or my obsession with these characters - I have been chain smoking these episodes like a demon. Totally great show.

Someone very close to me grew up in the Wild West and the lingo sounds very close to what actually transpired on the Frontier!

I have seen all three seasons, and all the episodes were exceptionally well written and scripted.  The actors are spot on in their portrayals. Of particular note is the poetic and philosophical commentary between the characters.  I found myself rewinding a number of times because there is a lot of depth in their conversations which can fly by rather quickly and is worth a second listen.  On another note, even though the story is fictionalized, it is based on the real town and the real inhabitants of Deadwood circa 1876.  It got me interested in the history of that area and the people in the series; Calamity Jane, Seth Bullock, Wild Bill, Hearst, etc.  The writers must have spent a great deal of time researching it themselves.  The only negative I could provide is that the series ends on season 3 without finishing the story.  I am not sure why HBO didn't continue with it; and now that so much time has passed, it is unlikely that it will ever be completed.  Great series though.

Season 2 of Deadwood continues to develop the ensemble of core characters. The question of territorial annexation no longer looms but the camp's ability to defend the legitimacy of the gold claims brings new conflicts. Outside pressures from the territorial capital and from wealthy industrialist George Hurst bend the characters in new and interesting ways-- often in excruciating scenes that do not relent.

The dialogue even becomes more Shakespearean, as the characters (especially Swearengen and Farnum) talk to themselves more or use their words to navigate the intentions and loyalties of those around them.

Having watched Deadwood in its entirety on a couple of occasions, I know that this season does lead in to a messy Third Season. Second viewing is very different from first viewing: I can see some of the decisions that will lead to problems in the final season. The Hurst storyline in particular-- especially on second viewing-- leads to some of the show's weakest episodes.

But all in all, Second Season does a remarkable job of maintaining tension in the story and sympathy for all of the characters (even some of the vilest ones).
Excellent cast and 'expletive' series. HOWEVER, ended with a whimper. Would like to see more. A lot 'expletive' more. OK.

Some might have found Deadwood to be too vulgar.  I say, "That's the sign of the times".  Deadwood was no dainty city.  Hell, it was barely a mudpatch in the Black Hills.  But Deadwood was Deadwood... wild and wooly with guns and whores for fun as well as life.

Timothy Olyphant plays a very believable character in Seth Bullock.  He's a former lawman who has headed west with his partner Sol Star (John Hawkes) who end up matching wits with or occasionally colluding with Al Swearengen (Ian McShane).  Love interests abound with Alma Garret (the lovely Molly Parker), the rich widow with a claim of some of the best producing ground in Deadwood.  Trixie (Paula Malcomson), plays the ever present 'hooker with the heart of gold'.  She and Sol ended up in some very interesting situations and conversations.

Deadwood portrays the area as accurately as possible.  They neither pull puncher nor sugar coat the world that was.  It's a helluva story.

Season 2 of Deadwood ramps up the tension as new alliances form, old rivalries fester, and civilization encroaches on a place that doesn't want to be totally civilized. Characters reach new heights as they cross boundaries between good sense and evil sensibility. In other words, the plotting is convoluted but very well portrayed. Ian McShane, of course, is stunningly brilliant. Similarly, supporting characters shine bright, including Calamity Jane and Trixie. The slight let down is Sheriff Bullock, who most of the time stands woodenly and seethes. Why? It's never quite clear other than that he's trying to control his impulse to shoot more people. Nonetheless, it is often distracting to the point of taking one away from the narrative. The only other criticism is the "retelling" of events as characters move from one group to another. The audience doesn't need a character to explain what just happened. It was seen on the screen. And the plot does move quite slow. But your time is well spent, deep in the bowels of a profane and vulgar place with a touch of humanity to keep it livable.

1877. The camp of Deadwood in the Black Hills is gaining respectability as the gold rush continues. It has a mayor and a sheriff, and the neighbouring territory of Dakota is expressing interest in annexing the nascent town.

The second season of Deadwood is a partially successful extension of the themes of the first season. Order has arisen out of chaos, a new government and law for the town has been formed and people are starting to organise themselves. Deadwood is still a dangerous place - life remains cheap for many - but civilisation is coming. Against this backdrop Al Swearengen is still running shady deals but he has now become involved in political intrigue as he tries to get the best deal possible for the town. Sheriff Seth Bullock's interest in law and order is put aside as he tries to get to know the family he has inherited from his brother, whilst Joanie Stubbs's attempts to go solo and open her own whorehouse end in tragedy. There's a wider variety of storylines and characters in the second season, but they don't cohere as perfectly as they did in the first.

The core problem is the essentiality of Ian McShane's presence as Al Swearengen to the success of the show. A curious decision was made to spend about three episodes on Swearengen being indisposed on account of kidney stones, meaning that for a quarter of the season its main protag/antagonist is all but absent, only appearing to pee some blood on the floor. Interesting for its attention to period detail (medicine in the 1870s was terrifyingly primitive), but hardly dramatically compelling. In McShane's absence, some of the thinness of the other character arcs becomes more apparent. Alma Garrett spends a dozen episodes sitting in her rooms not doing very much. Seth Bullock spends most of the season agonising over what to do about his relationship with his inherited wife and stepson (to the point of completely missing a prostitute-murdering killer being loose in the town). It's notable that the second season of Deadwood springs back to life when Swearengen returns to the front line, influencing an important part of history (Deadwood's acceptance into the USA and what territory it will join) from behind his office desk, negotiating deals with hugely important businessmen George Hearst and sorting out an internecine conflict within the Chinese community. Most of HBO's other classic shows succeed with broad ensemble casts, with no central role to hang the storyline on (The Wire, for example, had an entire year in which Dominic West's McNulty barely appeared and it was arguably the best season), but Deadwood falters in Swearengen's absence.

That said, even a slightly disappointing season of Deadwood remains great television. As with the first season, the writing, characterisation and attention to detail are all superb. The dialogue is often a joy to listen to, and the show's morbid sense of humour results in laugh-out-loud moments. Alma's indecision over her future prospects is presented sympathetically, but with a true-to-the-period emphasis on realism over sentimentality. Bullock goes through a similar process. Both storylines are drawn out much too long, but are nevertheless explored well. More successful is the way the show presents Cy Tolliver as a man with the veneer of civilisation and decency, but with a seething, frustrated anger not far below the surface.

The second season of Deadwood (****) remains compelling viewing, but definitely falters compared to the first year. The pacing feels sluggish at times and the back-room dealings over the camp's future feels like set-up more than the main course. The writing and performances remain exemplary and the thematic developments are fascinating, which help make up for the shortcomings.

I own copies of the entire "Deadwood" HBO series.  The reasons why this outstanding series was discontinued speaks to the advancement of greed over quality art.  Story line: OUTSTANDING! Now, perhaps that DID occur in reality, but I have a strong tendency to doubt it.  There is a prolific scattering of profanity, and ThAT I both believe happened, and it was correct to present it - as it was no doubt an integral part of the city/town/camp of "Deadwood".  I would recommend this entire series to anyone who has even a remote interest in the history of the United States and its' fabrications thorough some of its' historical happenings.  The viewer may not condone the depictions of events within the series, but, those things DID occur (with some poetic license thrown in), and it is beneficial to know of them.  I'd give this series ten stars if they were available.

Deadwood happens to be my second all-time favorite TV show, right behind Millennium. As a rapidly growing fan of Wild West cinema, I am mesmerized by the sharp revisionist approach that David Milch and company have taken. Guns are set aside as character, dialogue, and the look and feel of the gritty environment of the camp that's about to turn into a full-fledged town become the highlights of the show. The characters and their dialogue especially are what make this show. Seth Bullock, Al Swearengen, Calamity Jane, Doc Cochran, A.W. Merrick, Mr. Wu, and many others are memorable in their own right. The dialogue is some of the greatest I have ever heard on cable television. Modern-day Shakespeare becomes an untouchable art form.

When I bought the first season of Deadwood, I instantly fell in love with the entire show. Its high quality made me a fan. The second season is even better than the first, though with a couple of exceptions. For one thing, since there is a much bigger cast of characters in all twelve episodes, some characters don't get as much attention as others. I wish I saw a little more of Doc Cochran, Charlie Utter, Sol Star, Trixie, Jewel, and Hostetler. Also, William Bullock seemed to be the only character who seems unnecessary in the series. But then again, he IS loosely based on Bullock's actual biological son, so I'll give the creators credit for that.

Still, I can live with these minor flaws, as I truly believe that this is a brilliant second season. It's darker, grittier, wittier, and even more well-written than the first. In the end, however, I still love both seasons, though I give the second the slight edge. Now onwards to the third (and unfortunately the final) season.

Grade: 9.8/10

I'm fairly  new to Deadwood,  just finished season 2, waiting for 3.  I'll add to the chorus proclaiming this as one of the best things on TV ever. Be warned, though, that while season 1 was no "stroll in the park", season 2 is one of the darkest seasons I've ever seen on TV.

And not just emotionally dark.  Do you remember Apocalypse Now, how the film started sun-drenched and overly bright, and gradually the film's palette grew darker? Deadwood 2 feels very much like that.  Much more of this season is cast in darkness and shadow. Even the daylight outdoors scenes are darker than season 1.  And the mood and tone is incredibly dark.  Season 1 had more than its share of brutality.  Season 2 not only ramps up the brutality, but adds a lot of suffering to the mix.  There is pain in this season, to strip your heart like turpentine, and very little of joy.  The tonal darkness, the character's emotional darkness, and the coming political darkness all combine in a pretty harrowing fashion.

But there is transcendence and magnificence in abundance.  It continues as one of the most incandescent shows ever filmed, and all the lead actors from season 1 return in stellar fashion.  What is most striking in season 2 is how the women shine.  Mainly supporting players in season 1, Joanie, Jane, Trixie, Almah and Martha each have turns to truly shine in season 2, and they don't waste a minute of it.

It's profane, it's brutal, it's ugly, and it's best thing you've probably never seen.

Don't you dare start with season 2, but if you've seen season 1, don't dare stop now.  This is truly essential TV.
(NSFW, TV-MA)

This a wonderful and essential addition to the finest series on the Wild West that I have ever seen.  With the characters and situation established, the series really hits its stride in this season.  Swearengen and Bullock are the two principal characters, who after a brutal confrontation arrive at a kind of tactical alliance against other influences in the town and in favor of its development.  While they remain themselves as consistent characters, this introduces a shade of gray into the body politic, but their adversaries seem much much worse, from the mysterious Hearst to his strange henchman.

In terms of plot, the town is making big strides toward joining S. Dakota, but it is also becoming a major source of gold, attracting many fortune seekers and organizers.  To the credit of the writers and direction, what is happening in the maneuverings is not completely spelled out, leaving it to the viewer to piece it together over multiple viewings.  I find this a delightful thinking task to unravel the political machinations.  It also interests to search back to the real history - I discovered to my astonishment that most of the characters are based on historical figures, which I had assumed only made cameo appearences, like Wild Bill Hickock and Calamity Jane.  (Check out wikipedia in this regard.)  It got me to buy a bunch more books from Amazon, to learn more.  Of course, there is much that is added as fiction or is simply inaccurate, but it is stimulating and another layer that is extremely fun.

There is also much development of the secondary characters, such as a call girl, EB Farnum, or the doctor.  The actors are so good that they bring real pathos to the story.  Bullock's family is also a major theme, with his unloved wife and her son moving as representatives into the soul of the city.  There is tragedy and development, all realistic and tough.

I will watch these again and again.  HBO has accomplished a great new kind of narrative of the West.  Warmly recommended.

HBO in the early 2000s created a Golden Age for Television.  One of the shows in this golden age was Deadwood.  A Western based on the real town in the Dakotas is a work of  art.  Based partly on truth and mixed in with fiction, Seth Bullock comes to town to begin a business with his friend Sol Starr.  He soon finds himself up against an evil saloon proprietor named Al Swearengen.  In this season, Seth finally admits he loves Alma and discovers his wife has come to town at the same time.  He devotes himself to his wife and stepson and turns his back on Alma who is now pregnant with his child.  Al in the meantime is witnessing the changes in the camp such as the introduction of the telegraph.  Other characters are going through changes also.  Joanie Stubbs opens her own brothel and Sy Tolliver seems like a constant threat. A very good season of a great TV show.  Thank god for what HBO once was.
